messages: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:05): wonders what the next feature request from Henrik Dvergsdal will be
fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9 (19:06): the moon, on a stick?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:07): a <browser> tag that lets you embed a web browser in a page
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:10): <exe> lets you embed a local system executable
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:11): Finally real web applications (sort of)
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (19:15): can I request a <money> tag?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:15): I think we should also have <silly> as a generic container element for all these ideas... it works sort of like <object>
fefe4c60d912e295e59fd874577ca7f9 (19:16): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: with fallback content?
88a24f49777f8f698cfbd64b8a6d6da4 (19:16): <money id="euro">yes please</money>
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:18): I'd probably go for something like <money type="euro" src="bank" value="100">

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:20): What about actually making a black box element, though? Give it a type attribute and tell browsers who don't recognize it to ignore the contents completely. That should serve all the new ideas quite well
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:20): unsubscribes from www-html-editor
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:23): while you are joking about money markup, the microformats community may already be on the case
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:23): http://microformats.org/wiki/currency
88a24f49777f8f698cfbd64b8a6d6da4 (19:24): i prefer src="bank" better than target="bank"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:24): likes the way the microformats people hacked the URI syntax of their Wiki
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:26): What do you mean, e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0?
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (19:26): the microformats currency proposal is terribly verbose
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:26): concludes that hCard sucks for people who have multi-token given or family names (the reason why I'm reading their wiki)
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (19:26): the proposed markup is verbose, that is
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:27): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, lowercase and hyphenated
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:27): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, as opposed to camelCase
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:28): Well, they use mediawiki. It does away with camelcase in most uses
c938c62ecadcab91676bdf5e857fb8ca (19:28): Good day all.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (19:28): MediaWiki does Initial_caps by default
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:29): I never liked camelcase wikis myself
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:29): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: iirc vanilla mediawiki forces the first letter to be in the upper case and uses underscores
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:29): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: They still use underscores for spaces, they just name their pages with hyphens instead of spaces
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:29): (whatever the case really is, it's the first wiki where I see this being used)
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (19:29): that's why articles on wikipedia always start with an uppercase letter and have to make excuses when the actual item starts with a lowercase letter
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:30): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, ah, that could be ture
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:30): so maybe they haven't hacked it
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:30): The first-letter uppercase thing looks hacked
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:30): They removed the automatic page title too
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (19:30): oh, right
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:31): Or maybe some mw developer finally sat down and implemented the dual-title code that's been wanted for so long
